definition:
A poset is said to be *chain finite* if every chain with both and
minimal element is finite.

$\mathbb{Z}$ with the standard order relation is chain finite, since any
infinite subset of $\mathbb{Z}$ must be above or below. $\mathbb{Q}$
with the standard order relation is not chain finite, since for example
$\{ x \in\nobreak \mathbb{Q} \,\mid\, 0 \leqslant\nobreak x \leqslant\nobreak 1 \}$
is infinite and has both a maximal element $1$ and a minimal element
$0$.

Chain finiteness is often used to draw conclusions about an order from
information about its covering relation (or equivalently, from its Hasse
diagram).
